00040 #ifndef _physicsmanager_h
00041 #define _physicsmanager_h
00042 
00043 //forward Declarations so that we do not need #include "btBulletDynamicsCommon.h"
00044 class btAxisSweep3;
00045 class btDefaultCollisionConfiguration;
00046 class btCollisionDispatcher;
00047 class btSequentialImpulseConstraintSolver;
00048 class btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld;
00049 
00050 namespace phys
00051 {
00052     // internal forward declarations
00053     class World;
00054     namespace debug {
00055         class InternalDebugDrawer;
00056     }
00057     ///////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////////
00058     /// @class PhysicsManager
00059     /// @headerfile physicsmanager.h
00060     /// @brief This is simply a place for storing all the Physics Related functions
00061     /// @details This is a plage for storing items related to Debug physics
00062     /// drawing, Adding constraints, screwing with gravity and doing other physics
00063     /// Related features.
00064     class PhysicsManager
00065     {
00066         private:
00067             friend class World;
00068             //Some Data Items
00069             Vector3 GeographyLowerBounds;
00070             Vector3 GeographyUpperBounds;
00071             unsigned short int  MaxPhysicsProxies;
00072             //Real PhysicsStepsize; // use this->GameWorld->TargetFrameLength instead
00073 
00074             // Some Items bullet requires
00075             btAxisSweep3* BulletBroadphase;
00076             btDefaultCollisionConfiguration* BulletCollisionConfiguration;
00077             btCollisionDispatcher* BulletDispatcher;
00078             btSequentialImpulseConstraintSolver* BulletSolver;
00079             btSoftRigidDynamicsWorld* BulletDynamicsWorld;
00080             debug::InternalDebugDrawer* BulletDrawer;
00081 
00082 
00083             World* GameWorld;
00084 
00085             /// @brief This takes care of all the real work in contructing this
00086             /// @details This method is called by all the constructors to insure consistent behavior.
00087             /// @param GameWorld_ This is a pointer to the phys::World that this manager will work with
00088             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds_ This Vector3 will loosely represent the lower right conrer of the world
00089             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds_ This Vector3 will loosely represent the upper left conrer of the world
00090             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies_ This approximates the maximum amount of items allowed in the physics world
00091             void Construct(World* GameWorld_, const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_, const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_, const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies_);
00092         public:
00093 
00094             /// @brief Simple Constructor
00095             /// @details This constructor will assign some sane default values and will create a physics
00096             /// world that can be used immediately
00097             /// @param GameWorld_ This is a pointer to the game world this PhysicsManager will work with
00098             PhysicsManager(World* GameWorld_);
00099 
00100             /// @brief Simple Constructor
00101             /// @details This constructor will assign some sane default values and will create a physics
00102             /// world that can be used immediately
00103             /// @param GameWorld_ This is a pointer to the phys::World that this manager will work with
00104             /// @param GeographyLowerBounds_ This Vector3 will loosely represent the lower right conrer of the world
00105             /// @param GeographyUpperbounds_ This Vector3 will loosely represent the upper left conrer of the world
00106             /// @param MaxPhysicsProxies_ This approximates the maximum amount of items allowed in the physics world
00107             PhysicsManager(World* GameWorld_, const Vector3 &GeographyLowerBounds_, const Vector3 &GeographyUpperbounds_, const unsigned short int &MaxPhysicsProxies_);
00108 
00109             /// @brief This configures the Physics Manager to work with the Graphic settings
00110             /// @details This configures the Physics manager to work with the existing graphics settings. This must
00111             /// be called before the physics manager is used, but after the graphics have been initialized
00112             void Initialize();
00113 
00114             /// @brief Deconstructor
00115             /// @details This deletes all those crazy pointers that Bullet, the physics subsystem need.
00116             ~PhysicsManager();
00117 
00118             /// @brief Sets the gravity.
00119             /// @details Sets the strength and direction of gravity within the world.
00120             /// @param pgrav Vector3 representing the strength and direction of gravity.
00121             void SetGravity(Vector3 pgrav);
00122 
00123             /// @brief Enables and Disables Physics Debug Drawing
00124             /// @details Enables and Disables Physics Debug Drawing using default wireframes. This will force renderings that match the physics
00125             /// subsytem pixel for pixel.
00126             /// @param ToBeEnabled 1 to turn it on, 0 to turn it off. There may be other options in the future, to enable fine tuned control
00127             void SetDebugPhysicsRendering(int ToBeEnabled);
00128 
00129             /// @brief Is Physics Debug Drawing currently enabled?
00130             /// @details lets you check if Physics Debug Drawing is enabled or not.
00131             /// @return 1 for it is on, and 0 for it is not. The may be other options later for selectively cnacking certain features
00132             int GetDebugPhysicsRendering();
00133 
00134             /// @brief How many Wireframes do you want drawn from previous events
00135             /// @details Each frame of the action gets its own wire frame, and how many of those back did you want to see? To see a minimal amount
00136             /// set this to 2, as the first wireframe is commonly entirely inside the  the rendered 3d mesh. You can use World::GetTargetFrameTime()
00137             /// In conjunction with this to specify an amout of seconds worth of wireframes.
00138             /// @param WireFrameCount_ This is a whole number that is the amount of wire frames you wan to see. Don't forget to be mindful of the framerate,
00139             /// Any amount more than just a few seconds worth can be cumbersome.
00140             void SetDebugPhysicsWireCount(Whole WireFrameCount_);
00141 
00142             /// @brief This gets how many WireFrames are being drawn.
00143             /// @details This will tell you how many frames worth of previous in game events are being drawn.
00144             /// @return This returns either 2 or the last amount passed into World::SetDebugPhysicsWireCount .
00145             Whole GetDebugPhysicsWireCount();
00146 
00147             /// @brief This does all the work reuired for the main loop to process physics
00148             /// @details
00149             /// @param TimeElapsed This is a real that represents the amount of time we need to simulate
00150             void DoMainLoopItems(const Real &TimeElapsed);
00151 
00152     };
00153 }
00154 
00155 #endif
